Early access, but already playbale with some fun fights.

I do like the game, especially the direct PVP aspect where two teams of five directly fight over the last objective. Engagements can be very chaotic at the final moments due to the overwhelming amounts of dinosaurs, on top of enemy player attacks (sometimes it's even hilarious). Outsmarting opponents in those situations with reflexes, tactics, and teamwork is thrilling and satisfying, and achieving victory with an MVP title is ultimately the best reward in any team-games, including Exoprimal.

Exosuit actions are both smooth, flashy, on-point, and adequate. The developers successfully built unique personalities for 10 exosuits with only their moveset. If you played Warframe before, you can expect the more refined feeling of it in Exoprimal. If you never did, your actions are much lighter and faster than you'd think; they are not mechs nor tanks. Sci-fi aesthetics are also great, I'm a big fan of any good sci-fi world design. 

On the technical side, server connections are stable. I experienced 100ms+ lag during two matches, but other than that I had no noticeable issues. Optimization seems solid, no noticeable frame drops even at the most demanding combat sections. I do own a RTX 3080 and Ryzen 5600x so the game should run well, but since I've become a little skeptical of the recent AAA game launches, Exoprimal did surprise me.
So what I want to convey here, is that the development team has put effort and love to Exoprimal.

But since the Steam asks, "Do you recommend this game?", unfortunately I have to say "No" to that. I don't think that the Open Beta does not appeal to both the PVP and the PVE audience. 

As for the PVE component, your approach to the gameplay is neither diverse nor deep. It's shoot-to-kill.
One may argue that every PVE co-op shooter can be summarized into shoot-to-kill. However, other co-op shooters offer build customization so that each player can gear toward specialized tactics to effectively deal with certain enemies, and rely on teammates to defend against other threats. Exoprimal has no builds to speak of.
There are some enemy attributes that a player can exploit to gain an advantage, but the problem I see is that you keep repeating it over 75% of the match without the satisfaction coming from "I am achieving this thanks to my theory-crafting (or my strategic planning)". 
I enjoy playing as Roadblock the Tank, so here is how I play the game:

[list]
    [*]I toggle Taunt on, lean against a wall, and wait until my teamamates kill all dinosaurs.
    [*]If a dinosaur that can interrupt my Taunt spawns, I turn on Reinhardt Barrier instead, weave in some attacks, and wait until my teamamates kill all dinosaurs.
[/list]

Although I like protecting my teammates, it's hard for me to deny that what I do is repetitive. It's repetitive because there is nothing I can do to change up the gameplay. Battleborn featured gear customization and a skill-tree for both pre-matches and in-matches to promote experimentation and break tedium, but Exoprimal (or at least the Open Beta right now) does not.

This was why I said that the direct PVP combat was fun, because I know the situation will be different when facing off against human players. Despite the good direction and display, PVE encounters felt indifferent, even when swapping exosuits in a class. 
If you do want to experience something different then you will need to swap classes, but players in general don't prefer Tanks and Supports because they are regarded as "boring", "passive", and "not flashy" in a horde or a PVP game. And even if they do try them out, they will probably end up getting bored again (due to lack of builds and customizations - "depth").


As for the PVP aspect, again, only the direct engagements against human players were interesting. I assume that the designers wanted players to build team-cohesion first by introducing PVE and utilizing that as an asynchronous PVP challenge. I usually see this kind of gameplay in a mobile game, not a PC game, and I think that this is what the developers missed - people who own a gaming PC or a console are core gamers. 
Core gamers either prefer to directly compete against other players to feel superiority, or cooperate with others without getting stressed out from heated competitions. Core gamers tend not to like games that try to mix to two different genre. 
The two exceptions I know of are Sanctum series and Escape from Tarkov. But Sanctum still stays within boundaries of PVE shooter, and in Tarkov, players can choose to be stealthy and disengage to prioritize safety over loot. But in this Open Beta, there's nowhere to hide from repetitive AI-killing or human enemies.

Combat legibility and communication are poor in direct PVP combat. It can be difficult to tell what is going on at times due to sheer amounts of dinosaurs present on the last section. Each exosuit has a voiceline for when using an Ultimate, but I cannot tell if an ally or an enemy used it until I get hit. 
Ping system is decent enough, but they are inconspicuous. Pings players placed need to be bigger, more highlighted, and display target portrait so I can tell what info is being relayed by just looking at it. Pings should also be marked on the minimap. 
Dinosaurs block line-of-sight when attempting to ping enemy players which I find annoying. Enemy players should take top priority when targeting a ping. 'Enemy exosuit!' ping also has a bug where is removed shortly after pinging an enemy.
And I do not understand why pings and emotes share the same radial menu. They need to be separate. 

The balance between exosuits and classes feels decent, but there are some outliers. I believe that a good Zephyr - an aglie melee attacker - can really stomp the opposition thanks to his potent crowd-control for being an Assault. Skywave, a Support exosuit, probably has too much utility and evasiveness compared to other Supports. Vigilant is a sniper Assault and is seen every match. I find that she can do damage too easily when Deadeye has to constantly track enemy movement while also considering bullet velocity, and Barrage is unreliable in general.


So if you are wondering my final verdict based on this Open beta, it's "good for me, probably not for the general audience". They put effort to this game, it's by no means a half-assed game. But they should have presented two gamemodes for pure PVP and PVE players to leave a good first impression. Alternatively, they should have decided to entirely focus on a single genre during pre-production instead, but I'm afraid that they are way past that point.
I wrote this review as if I'm a PVP-oriented player but actually I play both, especially leaning towards PVE. So I'm expecting a prettier, better version of EDF as everyone is asking on the Steam forum. 

And finally, to whoever is the final decision maker - please consider making Exoprimal free-to-play, or at least lowering the price by two-thirds. I realize that's cutting a lot, but multiplayer games thrive on playerbase. If you put a massive paywall in front of potential buyers (especially with a new IP), it will be very difficult for the game to sustain its population. Exoprimal is also implying that there will be a season pass, which will make the overall price too expensive. Only famous games such as Diablo or Monster Hunter series can get away with this, since gamers know that those IPs can be trusted.

The new permanent upgrades are grindy yes, but they are also almost completely useless (except for the Emergency Safe and Core Beam). Instead, exactly like it was in the base game, there are a few things that you must hyperfocus on in order to thrive. Can't destroy the new caves? Try the Heavy Exosuit or the Seismic Suit anomalies. These both turn the caves to absolute dust, even at the very top. Having trouble defeating the enemies? Just like the Laser Gun in the base game, use the Locust Machine gun. 
This dlc is not hard, just slightly grindy. The main problem with this entire game is having a few really good anomalies and weapons, but leaving the rest as filler. The runs are boring because instead of figuring out a new strategy based on what you have, you just gotta pray you get a good item. A few small issues like audio bugs and accidentally starting the Zeus boss fight which restarts your run :(
Overall, very similar to the base game imo, and for less than $5 you can get a good 10 hours of gameplay if you want to 100%.

It amazes me to think how many people truly believe that they understand the meaning of pain. They wail about petty grievances and trifling discomforts while swaddled in their Miffy the Rabbit blankets, thinking themselves worthy of commiseration. 'I have pancreatic cancer,' they cry; 'my dad makes me call him "Honeypuff"', they lament. 

I curse these squalling babes. Every last one of them is irredeemable, save by the act of crawling in shame back into their mother's womb and cannibalising the slattern from within, as punishment for ever daring to bring them into a world not made for their kind.

My anguish, conversely, spans decades, and runs through my blood from the uttermost depths of my being. I have sworn fealty to the realm of Dransik since the beginning. Twenty years I served, languishing beneath swarms of bats and the molestations of giant spiders in search of higher purpose. Never before had pixels so bestirred my heart. Here were forged the most enduring and meaninful friendships of my life. And even in this unforgiving land of magma and impenetrable woodland teeming with carnivorous squirrels, betimes love did blossom, and my paramours and I gambolled about the meadows, petting sheep and smelling what were, if one squinted, most likely flowers. 

A life without Dransik was not one I could bear to contemplate. Alas, entropy is but one of many symptoms of the disease we name life, and sooner or later, the greatest of humanity's works all fall prey to rot. What exists on Steam today is merely a shadow of Dransik's former splendour. Gone are the early morning 200 player orgies, gone are the seal parades, gone is the thriving economy fuelled by the slave labour of hapless new players. It is a husk, a barren shell, an ensemble of bones dancing on puppet strings held by the careless and incompetent. 

Abandon all hope ye who enter here. Dransik is dead. Joy is dead. And soon I shall follow suit.

But considering it leans in on telling a serious story about as much if not more than it tries to fool around, frontloading the jokes seems like it was a bad call, especially when it doesn't do that much fun with the format.
It might have benefitted from even more fooling around and delivering a serious story in the manner of an off hand whimsy like it is no big deal.

Pros :
Better Character Models and animations
Better map textures
3 different game modes adding to re-playability
Various unlocks and achievements to earn through game play
Better and improvement detective notes, with more options to take notes as you play the game
Cosmetic Unlocks and Case Note Unlocks

MP Lobby bare bones and slightly bugged - lobby quite empty and thus is hard to get a game
SP Ai requires more work, as the game is too easy even on Hard difficulty

Occasional graphics glitch, but nothing too major (so far)

[b]Tales of Arise - Beyond the Dawn[/b] is probably the most eco-friendly DLC on Steam :
With over 90% recycled content, it undoubtedly cements itself as a game that thinks about the planet... but not about your wallet. (haha... it rhymes.)

Lots of great additions, but doesn't seem quite ready for prime time just yet.

While Atlas of Discovery adds new items, skills, dungeons, and all sorts of interesting new mechanics, I believe that the new Ancient Relic Mode is the primary draw for both newcomers and returning players. ARM offers a higher power and productivity ceiling than other modes; eventually it will lead to End-Game content and dungeons becoming much easier. I generally view Ancient Relic Mode as the most complete version of the game. Almost like a New Game Plus or Post-Game for a JRPG. Those exclusive rewards and power-ups are quite tantalizing.

My first impression of ARM was largely positive. Capping skill levels incentivizes players to explore laterally and consider using skills they may not have paid attention to in a previous playthrough. It's also great that players are mandated to prioritize combat abilities and clear dungeons to unlock non-combat content. Melvor has so much to offer, that it can be easy to inadvertently ignore combat and linger too long on the other skills. Even in idle games, players often want direction, and I suspect that many players can struggled to decide where to start with the combat. Ancient Relic Mode starts to mitigate what is probably Melvor's greatest flaw - a reliable progression between clearing dungeons and non-combat events. It's almost like the players are being asked to pair wine + cheese.

When a game has an incredible, even overwhelming amount of depth and numerous ways to succeed, limiting early player choice via a method like level caps is a good design decision. It can make the game more accessible, enjoyable and provide a more consistent experience. 

Unlocking Ancient Relics and the accompanying skill power-ups also seem pretty awesome  - I'm happy with this feature so far.

Unfortunately, while ARM is advertised as challenging and requiring active play, that doesn't mean I was expecting it to be so punishing and restrictive - at least not until significantly later in the game. I bought AOD the day of release, and I came in with a decent understanding of the core mechanics. So it doesn't make much sense that I am stalling out and getting frustrated before being able to clear the second dungeon. And that even though I've capped most skills to their max of 10, 15, or 25, I'm being held back by a very annoying lack of more available recovery items. There is no good reason for this type of delay or requiring so much active grinding - I've barely gotten into the good stuff. This is especially alarming since I own the Throne DLC and because it will be an even larger barrier to entry for beginners and more casual players.

AOD adds 2 new skills: Cartography + Archaeology. Both seem like good additions, but since I'm focusing on my new ancient relic mode, I haven't explored much past 10. They both seem feature-rich and fun, and offer the discovery the DLC advertises. But neither seems fully polished. I was surprised by the choice not to offer simple in-game tutorials or a more expository in-game guide. The difference between survey and auto-survey seems wonky and weird! Why can't we manually survey more tiles when auto-survey can do so indefinitely? Sometimes we can set sail for only a short distances (in hexes) away. The open seas are supposed to be liberating but even the active game-play isn't too flexible.

Map-making and usage (for Archaeology digs) feel unnecessarily complicated and confusing; I couldn't even figure out how I was supposed to operate the first free map I was given. There are other indications improvement is needed. Does it really make sense to create the maps (and paper) needed for Archaeology in the Cartography menu? Not completely and it would make much more sense with a smoother execution.  Cartography and Archaeology still do many things I like, especially with checkpoint rewards - its a bit early for a full verdict.

I haven't commented on all the new features; There are many areas I haven't had a chance to explore yet but I have seen enough to trust I will be satisfied with the amount of added content. For example, the new lesser relic consumables appear to be well implemented and useful.

While I don't regret my purchase, I think that Ancient Relic Mode would greatly benefit from some early-game tweaking and possibly additional balance changes. That being said, I am fairly confident that the developers will patch in some timely improvements and be responsive to any upcoming concerns from the player base about their experiences.


Edit: Changed my review from thumb up to thumb down but please know steam is forcing me to express my review in a format I don't really like. DLC doesn't need to be evaluated by the same standard as a stand-alone game. This DLC is very promising and its execution errors seem fixable. Players who enjoyed the base game may choose to support the devs with a purchase even if they don't think the product is fully ready.


UPDATE: Since writing the review I've discovered an obscure feature called "spam eating" allows many players to clear dungeons that they could not clear otherwise. I don't think there are any in-game indications about the feature. I thought potatoes could only restore 3-6 hp/second not 30-60 hp/second (estimated); That's a HUUGE difference! This should be addressed.


One final note. The devs have repeatedly emphasized their desire to design all DLC (including future DLC) as standalone content with complimentary effects. This is a praise-worthy goal, but it may prove more challenging and risky than expected.

[h1][b]THE SHORT GAME OF THE PRINCESS[/b][/h1]
Sometime ago, i'm pretty sure I saw this game on DLsite or some other website, but I didn't bother picking up, though I couldn't quite remember why. After playing it briefly, I realized that i'm glad I didn't double-dip on this one-- it's a very short experience, and the difficulty lies in whether you choose to have Estelle lose her virginity or not. Anyway, let's begin this review.

[h1][b]THE STORY[/b][/h1]
The story in this game is basically laid out for you in the first few minutes of the game, the game's synopsis, and if you scroll down and look under story. How do I feel about the story? It's bland, like the majority of H games out there. It's not the first time this sort of premise has been used, and there's quite a few strategy games that employ this sort of plot device that you can pick up on DLsite if you scrounge around a little and look for SLGs.

[h1][b]THE GAMEPLAY[/b][/h1]
Pretty simple, you can move your units as many tiles as you want if they're your tiles(indicated in blue). Touching an empty red tile or trying to attack an enemy will end the turn of the unit that was moved, and if the enemy on a tile is defeated, you will capture the tile as well. Aside from that, I mostly found myself using the archer to chip away at enemies on first hit, deal damage with the soldier, and then finish off with mage. I almost never utilized the Knight or Armor Knight, and somewhat utilized the Guardian Dragon-- they do virtually no damage and cost too much to heal to be worth using.

Don't engage an enemy if it puts you in a point where 2 or more enemies can attack you at once, try to bottleneck them if you're having issues. As stated earlier, the game's difficulty lies in whether Estelle is a virgin or not, and there ARE endings tied to the state of her chastity. With how short the game is, learn the game by popping her cherry as soon as you can, then go for the virgin ending on the second run; the game's short enough, and easy to understand to do as such.

[h1][b]THE GRAPHICS/VISUALS[/b][/h1]
Aside from Estelle and the CGs, everything else, from backgrounds, to units, etc were stock assets in RPGmaker, Wolf Editor, and various other engines  that you can lift assets from.

[h1][b]THE AUDIO/BGM[/b][/h1]
Much like the graphics, everything is stock-standard stuff you can lift from various engines and websites, with the exclusion of Estelle's voice actress. In other words, basically nothing to write about, though I will admit that I enjoyed the vocal performance, it was pretty expressive in a good way.

[h1][b]THE H CONTENT[/b][/h1]
I have to say it every time I write a review for an H game:
This is the section all of you are interested in.
To summarize, it's mostly just PZR, Mouth stuff, non-con, and eventually consenting(mild corruption, I guess). There's a few tags that some might be interested in, namely Somnophilia and Hypnosis, but it's very light, and there's only like... 8 CGs with a few variations. The H content is light, in other words. If you're a complete freakin' weirdo like me and have been in the H game scene for over a decade, you'll definitely find this game's H content severely lacking(alongside the game itself...).

[h1][b]MY PERSONAL ENJOYMENT[/b][/h1]
I'll be honest, I was strongly considering filing for a refund. The game definitely isn't worth $8, especially with how long it is, but I played it long enough that I could consider it a "minimum wage" level game, so for what it's worth, if you consider game duration versus price, then it's priced properly.

The game itself wasn't very fun to play, and gave no explanation on how to actually play the game, but it's not difficult to understand. Did I enjoy it? No, not really, but it made an hour slide right by, so I guess it's somewhat okay, at best.

[h1][b]THE CONCLUSION[/b][/h1]
The Winning Secret of the Newbie Strategist Princess is kind of a pain to play, but there's definitely worse out there. If you want to be silly, you can probably just pick the game up, grab the adult patch from OTAKU Plan's website, and maybe get a quick fap, then refund the game after. The game's short enough to do all of that within the refund window.

[h1][b]THE VERDICT[/b][/h1]

Shattered Land Tips: 
- If you want to speed up the gameplay turn off animations (hotkey: "A")
- You can pre-buff area affect spells by having your full party visible (hotkey: "5")
- Thieves deal sneak attack damage when behind a creature (creature must be facing opposite direction)
- The game may try to force you to end your turn through a toggle (using all movement, being 'stuck' from a spell/effect), close the toggle and you can continue fighting (shoot, spell, attack adjacent enemies).
- You'll gain a lot of XP playing through the game so creating characters with at least 2 classes is definitely worth it (I beat the game with 3 characters with 3 classes, and one with 2 classes and they were all near max level by the end, so would definitely be max at 2 classes each)
- You can max your stats/hp by clicking the box next to the number during character creation (max constitution before maxing HP)
- There is a 'default' party by loading the game and pressing start game without creating any characters
- Money is nearly useless so don't worry about looting everything
- Haste is the best spell
- Dual wielding weapons gives no determinable penalty and you can attack more
- Some higher-end enemies can destroy your armour / weapons permanently, so keep an eye out for the text (it flashes quickly).
- Clerics are unique in Dark Sun; each elemental sphere of cleric has its own unique (and small selection) of spells. Clerics never learn healing spells or resurrections other than Cure Minor Wounds, while Druids get Cure Serious Wounds, and Cure Critical Wounds, as well as the Raise Dead spell. Clerics are seriously under powered/low-utility.

- Left shift key skips the opening videos
- The default Half-Giant gladiator character (Gerakis) starts with a special weapon, so start with him and transfer the weapon over and drop/add a new character in his place if you want the weapon but not the character. (may also appear in inventory of new parties?)

It's incomplete. I can't describe it any other way. It has some growing pains it will likely go through in the near future. I think the first thing to address is my headset because it causes the most incompatibility with games I've seen so assume anything that relies on it (height, tracking, controllers, etc.) could just randomly have problems. That aside, some games work well on it, so I know it's possible.

(I think) headset related bugs:
-Sprinting it difficult to activate unless you're looking at your hands, likely due to camera positions + how it reads the up and down movement, I would've preferred a more accelerometer based approach but this might have been more reliable idk.
-The 'abxy' buttons are not mapped by default so dash and jump need to be mapped. I published my config, all it is is abxy mapped.
-Reaching over your shoulder or for your side weapons in difficult, they don't line up on my body.
-My arms/shoulders are like a second set of arms beneath my arms that meet at my hands, this wouldn't be an issue if they couldn't collide, but collision is important for realism so idk.
-Response to controller movement is average, which would be better if it didn't rely so heavily on it working.
-My height felt all wrong, I left it on auto but even when I set it manually, things felt off.
With WMR/Reverb G2 issues out of the way:
-The weapon rack had the executioner's sword off center, and it's trigger would prevent you from grabbing swords next to it even if your hand was essentially touching the other sword because it's trigger area is so large. 
-The ice magic staff I assume is meant to represented by the top diagram on the stone pillar but it's diagram is clockwise, just like the fire, when it's actually counter-clockwise for the spell.
-Dialogue is all but inaudible when not staring basically right at the character.
-Triggering the bell at the blacksmith is challenging.
-The tutorial has a boss, this boss is fun but nothing about the consequences of dying were explained (matter, weapons on the ground, potion loss, etc.)
-The way you are intended to move the panels when ordering at the blacksmith is unclear: can you grab it, or only slide it, why is it so hard to trigger? 

Now I've griped, let's talk about what they did right, which is what I'm very happy with and why despite what I mentioned above, I played for 2 and half hours without taking off the headset.
1) SteamVR. It works great, and binding adjument on the fly worked a charm. What buttons 1 and 2 were wasn't clear but everything worked so it's fine.
2) Game feel. I felt immersed, wanting to swing my sword with accurate and powerful blows (though the speed might not affect damage, idk). This is a game I can see myself playing again and becoming invested in the story and progression of.
2a) Magic. Very fun, balanced by limits on knockback, shields, and mana pool. At first I thought it would make it too easy but mana regen speed means that when your pool is empty, you feel more at ease if you pull out a sword or hammer to fight with while your mana regens. I've got the ice and fire staves and they have similar function-ish with great recognition of what is and isn't the right shape, only wish it worked vertically. Can't have your cake and eat it too, i guess.
2b) Weapons. With immersive combat comes a need for fun and varied weapons, and what better way to serve that than by giving that? You have axes, swords, hammers, daggers, spears, shields, and magic staves all of which have multiple variants to craft. Choose handle, blade shape, guard, etc. 
2c) Potions and materials. You lose all but your starting potions when you die (provided they are unused) but materials aren't kept with you. Both materials and potions are 'hidden' throughout the places you might engage in combat. Materials are for weapons, they are schematics (for the previously mentions weapon building) and resources like wood, iron, and gems. Potions are used to recover health and/or mana should you choose to use them. They can be found the same way as materials: as occasional drops or as loot/hidden treasure.
3) Skill tree and armor. I like that your armor is free and interchangeable depending on your build, just like resetting your perks is so you're very free to explore different playstyles. Health regen to compensate for choosing heavy armor? nice. things like that.
4) Switching it up. There isn't a time I've encountered (except when I died, all enemies respawn if you die, loot doesn't, go collect your corpse) that made me feel bored. I never thought about quitting because there was nothing different. The story doesn't force too much on you and it plays easily, keeping your interest the while time.
5) Menus. Pause is a thing (not): you can press your settings button and the game keeps going and you're still able to move. Accepting quests and interacting with the guide felt very natural. I especially liked the nod to accept.

Overall, I'd say they've got work to do, and not just for WMR. Bugs are common in a early access game and I really look forward to what this looks like in a few months when it's more mature. Overall, I recommend this game with the understanding that what you;re getting is still being worked on and it not done yet. Also. the herbalist looks weird (so does the old man, but that's just old people). To devs reading this, good luck, I can see you really care about making this a great game.

EDIT: Switching the resolution to the lowest setting actually helped the game run better, and I no longer have consistent performance issues. If you're trying to switch your resolution, you have to try pressing the arrow keys AND enter before it updates. It's an entertaining game for sure, I got it again because of the patch fixing performance issues so I could give it another honest try.

[h3]Title: Cozy Fishing[/h3]

[b]Introduction:[/b]
Cozy Fishing is a game about, well, fishing. The fishing mechanic itself is very similar to Stardew Valley, except the bar is shorter and sideways. There are four main fishing maps, plus an aquarium to keep track of each of the 20 different species of fish you have caught.

[b]Graphics and Atmosphere:[/b]
The game has a fairly calm atmosphere. There isn't much to see but there are atmospheric sounds. The graphics are good looking and overall the game has very little visual bugs as far as I can tell.

[b]Gameplay and Achievements:[/b]
The entire objective of the game is to catch all of the fish. Something that can be done within very little time, even the most casual of game fan can finish this game in one sitting. There are no descriptions to the fish you catch, no additional content other than catching the existing 20 fish species. Some fish do seem rarer than others, I spent half of my short game time just trying to catch the sunfish.
On the other hand, getting all the achievements is fairly easy since they are tied to catching certain fish, which as mentioned takes almost no time at all. 

[b]Issues and Challenges:[/b]
I only really found one visual issue, that being on the last map, where water seems to go into the boat but that is by no means any sort of game breaking bug. 
This game is no challenge at all.

[b]Replayability and Longevity:[/b]
There is little to no repeatability. This game is easy to complete and features almost no content. 

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
If you like repetitive games with little to no substance or are just looking to increase your achievement count, then this game is for you. The atmosphere is not nearly cozy enough to keep me playing, especially because of the lack of any sort of additional features. If you are planning on getting this game, I would suggest getting it on sale, despite the low price tag.
 
I don't like not recommending games but at the current state I can't give a recommendation without feeling bad about it. If I could give it something in between, I would.

[b]On a different note: the developer(s) seem(s) to be working on their next game and I'm exciting to see what they put out in the future, since this is by no means a bad game.[/b]

I have been waiting for this one to come out. Where to even begin.

The game is basically an auto chess clone, with sprinkled in eroge. There is no "city management" to speak off. The game  basically consists of 2 phases. The base phase, where you can upgrade your income, number of units you can deploy etc., and the battle phase, and you have to repeat this for 40 days(turns) So far nothing special.

The meat of the game is basically in its second phase, where you buy and deploy your units in formations, and let them duke it out with the opponents. Your units all have different abilities of their own, and have 4 different classes and races which provide various bonuses if you deploy more of the same race or class, and you can even upgrade your units by buying more copies of them from the store, which randomly offers you units which you can refresh for some extra gold.

This can provide some replay value because otherwise the battles aren't random, no matter how many times you start over the game, battle 10 or battle 12 will have the same enemy lineup, but you can't see said lineup before the battle starts, you have to remember.

Before I get to the eroge part of the game, it's also worth pointing out, that before you start a campaign, you can build a deck containing 10 abilities, like reduce lust by 20 for 200 gold, or next battle your units will deal 8% damage. These abilities are basically what you can decide to use in the town phase, the only problem is, that some of these skills are mandatory, so if you unequip them you are certain to lose. One such skill is the reduce lust, cuz if your lust meter reaches max, its game over.

Now on to the Eroge part. The game is trying to please the corruption lovers (its all about letting your character turn in to a succubus or resist and remain pure), but sadly, the writing and the translation is....not the best, so enjoying them can be difficult.

The art is also hit and miss. Some CG looks good, but some looks pretty bad.

You can also have unique events with certain units if you've bought them, but those are few and far between. (Yes this isn't just a Yuri, there are male "encounters" too)

Overall the eroge part of the game, leaves me with mixed feelings. It's not bad, but the simplistic writing/translation (not sure which one to blame) makes enjoying them pretty difficult, then there is a the mediocre CG.

But the actually game, and the whole corruption process is overall good. It's definitely worth the price. After you've beaten the game there is also an endless mode.

After a 110 hours of Stellaris overlord and not touching grass, this is what I think of the new DLC...

Vassals:
Before the update, vassalization was one of my favorite parts of Stellaris...
It still is.
The fact the entire vassal system for the base game was changed overnight, is going to cause problems and it has.

It can let you delegate micromanagement of planets to AI, whilst getting resources for it, to avoid mental illness.

I did not have any major problems with the vassal system as I kept the loyalty at max at all times. It seems that subjects have become more powerful to the overlord. I don't like that you need very niche conditions (subject has inferior technology) to be able to negotiate integration.

Scholarium - Taking 45% of basic resources, and 75% of technology, with extra research bonuses, of a 20 planet empire is overpowered, whilst also lowering subject naval capacity (so they don't rebel) is very useful. This is my favorite vassal type.
Bulwark - Expensive for both subject and overlord; useful for defensive purposes as subject gets defensive bonuses.
Prospectorium - Basic resources in exchange for science. Best for resource rich, and science poor subjects.
Subsidiary - Basically: the rich get richer, and the poor get poorer. Useful for taxing resources. That's all they do.
Protectorate - The only type of vassal that can be integrated. Subsidiaries can automatically become converted to protectorate if they fall behind overlord in technology.

I was not disappointed with the new vassal system, although I found that an empire on the other side of the galaxy had 3 bulwark vassals which seemed a bit broken, and gave them an edge over all other empires. I am not sure about the vassal rebellion system though, as I kept the subject loyalty high.

Megastructures:
The megastructures are the best part about this DLC, all of them have uses (apart from quantum catapult).

Quantum Catapult - Virtually useless by the time you can built it; just use gateways or wormholes.
Matter Decompressor - Can be useful without vassals, but subsidiaries can give you minerals anyway; situational.
Hyper Relays - Very useful for transportation, almost replaces gateways; acts as a galactic gateway.
Orbital Rings - They are just a mini starbase on your planet, that can enhance it (i.e. add districts, increase production).

Enclaves:
The enclaves make the game more interesting, and can make military fleet management in the game stronger and more versatile.

Salvager Enclaves - Never had a need to scrap ships for alloys, I prefer to scrap them in combat, and only one spawned in a huge galaxy; mostly irrelevant.
Mercenary Enclaves - AI likes spamming these whenever possible. They are useful, but take up a lot of naval capacity, and cost a lot of resources to maintain. You can destroy them to remove the fleet that an AI player is renting, however they will eventually build another mercenary enclave anyway.

Conclusion:
If you're planning on completing a full grand admiral difficulty game on a huge map, it's better to not buy the DLC and touch grass. It took 5 real life days to complete the last 100 years, on a mid to high end PC with this DLC, which contributed to more game lag. 

However, This DLC makes the game more interesting, which is good, despite the insane lag of having 6-8K empire population, which the game wasn't optimized to handle, nor was the DLC.

[i]Roma Invicta[/i] is a strategy game that combines turn-based conquest management with real-time battles. It has a lot in common with the [i]Total War[/i] franchise, but obviously without the massive AAA budget. The core gameplay involves back-and-forth battles between the Roman invaders and the Gallic tribes defending their territory.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
You start out on a small campaign map of Western Europe. Your mission is to start in Italy and eventually conquer every region on the map. There’s a basic supply system that requires you to feed your soldiers, as well as an economic system that gives you money to spend on food and soldiers, but it’s extremely straightforward to the point where it feels dumbed-down. Not everything needs to be a grand strategy game full of political intrigue and complex economic simulation, although a little more depth would have been appreciated.

Once you get into the real-time battles, it becomes more challenging. The AI isn’t spectacular, yet it still manages to provide some much-needed difficulty. The limited amount of possible army compositions means that you will usually fight with the same units, give or take a few. Strategically, you’ll always be trying to execute the same general plan, just with some minor twist. It gets stale after a while, but the game is pretty short and doesn’t overstay its welcome.

After playing the campaign, you can try out the custom battle mode, which removes the strategic map and focuses only on the real-time battles. It’s a nice bonus but ultimately didn’t do much for me. This may change with the recent addition of Steam Workshop support, but this review was written a few days before that feature existed, so I can’t say how meaningful it is.

[h2]Presentation[/h2]
I loved the graphics, despite them being a little odd-looking. Every part of a soldier is modeled individually and it’s cool to see all the different moving parts during combat. The tradeoff is that performance is significantly worse than it would be with traditional animations. It didn’t impact my enjoyment, although it might be a deal-breaker for someone with an older PC.

[h2]Verdict[/h2]
[i]Roma Invicta[/i] is far from a perfect game, but considering the price and its low-budget indie status, it comes out looking fine. It manages to do more things right than wrong, I just wouldn’t give it a strong recommendation. Fans of the [i]Total War[/i] franchise might enjoy it as a smaller, less complex version of those games, although it probably won’t scratch the same itch.

[h2]6/10[/h2]

TL;DR: A single tiktok managed to set expectations for this game in such a misdirection, that everyone came in expecting a successor to Green Hell or whatever else came to their mind. This game is nothing like that. I doubt that was the only reason for the game being hyped up, but it was at least for the initial hype. Paired with the performance issues at launch, that's the main reason why people reviewed it negatively. Most never played the whole thing because they weren't able to at launch, but you are now. It's just a 3 hour long story-based game about a dude trying to escape an island. Just try it out, it's free, no harm in doing so. Just give it a chance, don't ignore it because of the reviews. But that’s just my opinion.

If you're reading the comments, deciding whether or not to get this game because of it's negative reviews, I'll give my honest opinion on the game here, but let me tell you something first: This game is a really good example of how TikTok can completely fuck people over. 

The main reason for the massively negative response is the fact that 1.5 (as of this review being made) million people saw a video on TikTok about the game, and like I, decided to wishlist for what the TikToker said, taking their word for what this game would be. Looking back, this game is nothing like that review, and my only guess as for why is because the TikToker saw the "Explore, Solve, Fight" tag and assumed that it would be like Green Hell or Sons Of The Forest. It didn't help that it also had "Online CO-OP" as a tag, which the TikToker spun into  playing with friends. His entire account is just lazy, he does that with every game releasing that there's no info on. It probably took him 30 seconds to read the steam page and then another minute to spin that into something that would get him views. He mentioned so much stuff that was undoubtedly enough to hype people up for the game. This set people up with the hope that it would be this and that, have survival elements, be CO-OP, basically so much more than what the dev had really put on his steam page. A single steam page. That's not even enough to base what a game is like on, and yet all these people assumed that it would be whatever they thought it would be. 

This game is nothing like what that guy said on TikTok, and that's okay! Honestly, it's an amazing free game, I was running it on max settings and it ran fine, the areas looked gorgeous, enemies looked terrifying, and the people looked realistic. It's a short game, only took me ~3 hours to beat, but for a free game, you're getting a lot. The story is almost like a COD campaign, where you can replay missions and its entirely story centered. You play as Jeremy, a teen who is along for the ride investigating an island. His group gets separated, and picked off, and Jeremy must escape from the island. The story has a few twists, and the ending is pretty shocking, and overall the story is decent. Felt a little bit too twisty, in my opinion, but I don't think its unbearable. The puzzles are interesting, and actually make you think. Some of them I understood in seconds but other people had to ask on the community page, which I see as a good thing, if it's able to get people thinking and the community helping each other.

Sure, the performance wasn't amazing, but definitely better than expected. I just want to close this review out by saying please be kind, supportive, and give feedback to the dev, even if negative. Just remember the fact that he created all of this alone, put his own time into it, and possibly his own money. What did he get in return? A game that was drowned in negative reviews by people who played expecting what some random dude on the internet said, and a game that would be perfect at launch. Think about how it feels to him. Negative reviews are fine, but be more constructive than "The guy on tiktok lied :steamsad:" because this dev isn't even affiliated with him.

So consider this a neutral recommendation. I honestly wasn't having fun playing this game. However, I do think that others may find it more appealing. I really thought this would bring back the nostalgia of Paperboy, which I have fond memories of playing as a kid. However, this game really didn't bring back those fond memories at all. Unlocks are also very easy at first, then you grind to almost a total halt, having to replay levels to try to get that extra challenge done.

Game is running on the Unreal Engine 5.1, but I honestly wouldn't have guessed that. Performance was less than optimal, although I was getting mostly 90 fps on my RTX 3080, I would get severe frame rate drops at times along with some stutters. Which is odd because the visuals were less than stellar, especially around the waterfalls. The music also wasn't that great, which is a must for an arcade type title. 

I think others might enjoy this game more than me. However, as a hardened VR veteran with over 10k hours in VR, I just wanted to stop playing at about the hour mark. And that is exactly what I did. Hopefully, the game gets much better once it leaves Early Access. Maybe some future updates improve the game substantially. Right now, it's just lacking for me personally.

There are things I like about Bonding Ambivalence. Namely,
-The sound design (especially the soundtrack)
-The visuals (there are less interesting parts, but certain enemy designs and visual set-pieces really stand out)
-The combat (satisfying and cathartic after spending so long on puzzles)

That said, I would be lying if I said I generally enjoyed playing the game beyond it being something to do with a buddy.

-The puzzles, whilst sometimes clever and interesting, are typically gated behind finding a particular panel or object that is far from easily spotted. Often, my buddy and I would be stuck, wondering how on earth you were supposed to solve a puzzle, only to discover that we hadn't checked some random corner to get the item / flip the switch we needed.

-The roles, while neat in theory, often boil down to the hacker getting to do most of the fun stuff (hacking terminals to their benefit, having access to most of the information needed to progress, and wielding better guns with more ammunition) while still participating in the team activities. Leaving the infiltrator to mostly just walk around trying to find some bio-data they can scan, or a panel they can open. (admittedly, I was the one playing the hacker, so this is based on second-hand information) Supposedly the infiltrator's draw is their mobility and stealth, but their mobility consists of the ability to slip into a few infiltrator-only zones (leaving the hacker to wait for them), the ability to jump (which my buddy confirmed after playing that it was never once necessary, or even useful), and ~possibly~ a faster running speed (by the end of the game we weren't sure, so take this one with a grain of salt). As for their stealth, to quote said buddy "There was literally never an opportunity to sneak past anything."
-The story is serviceable, though the antagonist never felt particularly threatening/interesting/memorable to me. Of course, this is rather subjective.

Overall, there is plenty of potential for a great game here, and at times, the game realizes it's potential, but as far as enjoyment goes, constantly waiting for each-other in sections where only one person can act, and banging our heads against the wall at dead-ends made for an experience I thoroughly didn't enjoy. And I was playing the funner role.

Still, the game might be for you if you're super observant and have a duo who's just as observant. Provided one of you is willing to play the infiltrator.

Foreword: Don't buy this if you are computer illiterate. Transition from the hub-world to some of the games wasn't always so crisp and there were plenty of technical difficulties that would make most people tear their hair out or just drop the experience entirely. I had compatibility issues with every Unreal Engine game and intense screen-tearing in the hub world despite v-sync. I have a pretty standard 60hz monitor and a 2080 Super so things should have been fine.... That said...

This has been one of my favorite video game experiences of all time. It is my first (and hopefully not last) Dread X Collection. The games are a mixed bag, the hub level is full of screen-tearing, and the unreal engine games in the pack have to be played in Windows 7 compatibility mode... but man, what a ride. 

It felt like I was playing through a Creepshow movie. Every game was it's own short, new horrific scenario. And there is something incredibly satisfying about playing through what basically amounts to experimental game design. When it works, it feels like you've discovered something new and exciting. When it doesn't work, it still feels like an interesting experience. And they are all short enough to where you don't feel like your time was wasted if you didn't like one. At least not significantly. 

There were a few games where the means of progression felt tedious, repetitive, or unreasonable, not in difficulty, but in practice. I really don't like QTE's and they weren't set up well for controller in Gallerie (maybe I should have lowered the difficulty?). Interim should have never tried timed platforming, though there wouldn't really be a game-play aspect to it otherwise. And finally, why wasn't there an in game end game for Ludomalica? You just go around and around the game board with no end in sight? It nearly made me think that the game had no ending whatsoever and I nearly put it down. I'll also briefly mention that last chase in Beyond the Curtain. The hit-boxes were unclear and I had to restart it about five times. Atmosphere and horror go by the wayside when all you feel is frustration.

I won't write down my least favorite, I feel like the developers deserve respect for what they've made. These were all small teams and I still enjoyed a technical aspect of the one I really didn't like. 

But far and away my favorite was We Never Left. It was exceptionally well crafted, tight in story AND technical execution. I don't get scared at video games or films, I'm too desensitized to them. I understand too much about how games are made to be frightened. But We Never Left made me excited to [spoiler] look out and see if what was on the computer had affected the game world. [h1]In-Depth[/h1]
[h3]Setting & Writing[/h3]
An alternate history 1999 has humanity colonizing most of the solar system thanks to the discovery of advanced artificial gravity generation, which allowed long-range space faring and the construction of stations and outposts alike. Protagonist David is an ordinary nobody, broke as hell and living in a claustrophobic concrete cubicle somewhere on Earth. The solution to his problems approaches unexpectedly when, at the beginning of the story, he gets recruited for a well-paying job on a far-away fuel extraction station - the titular Titan Station, that is. In a ‘Space Odyssey-esque’ environment that blends high tech with 80s aesthetics and laughably impractical furniture, many interesting things are yet to happen to our unsuspecting character.

Yours will be a speaking protagonist with most of its dialogue choices predetermined, while some of them will be up to you, choosing between a limited series of replies to other characters. The quality of writing is more than passable, however the acting doesn’t always hold up, as David (and also other characters) won’t always sound as preoccupied, anxious or startled as he should, during the more conceited situations in his time at the station. Notably enough, there doesn’t seem to be multiple endings or ‘wrong’ dialogue responses that may lead to different events or ‘failures’; whatever you reply, the result will be the same in the grand scheme of things - which is somewhat disappointing, especially in a few cases where more could’ve been done to emphasize smart thinking.

Nevertheless, the narrative, dialogues and plot evolve in a mostly interesting manner, with a constant influx of turnarounds and new information that keep interest up. It’s a shame that the latter phases of the story feel rushed, as far as narration is concerned, with massive ‘exposition dumps’ typical of a story that wanted to say more, but then the development budget went dead-ass broke and they had to somehow put a patch on it. Or the writers just were lazy, the result stays the same. Overall good… enough.

[h3]Exploration & Dialogues[/h3]
The space sprawl extends on multiple layers, connected by a multitude of service tunnels, airlocks and sections that each require specific authorization levels to get through. Most of it will be blocked at first, as you’ll have to follow the orders of the commander, Jack, and proceed with your tasks; doing so will generally give you, in one way or another, the means to access previously-locked-out parts of the station. There is a decent number of files, datapads and documents to find and sift through, that will give you a better idea of what the other crewmates have been up to, and about what happened before you arrived. Some narration relies on environmental clues and indirect means, so not everything will be conveyed through files or recordings.

Dialogues are mostly held through radio or other comms equipment: they’ll have you choose different ways to reply or questions to ask sometimes, but in general they will be linear dialogues with minimal differences. Nothing will change majorly depending on your answers or choices, even if sometimes I felt like it should have been a thing. A missed opportunity for narration surely, however the story itself remains good, even if without a meaningful choice component.

[h3]Puzzles & Objectives[/h3]
In general, your tasks will be straightforward and entail finding a series of items to use in a specific order. This is kind of the first type of puzzle, which could be classified as a ‘hidden object’: finding codes or items to proceed forward, like a door code, a keycard upgrade, and so on. There’s another type of puzzle as well, that takes place in virtual reality and will have you connect rows of colored cubes, as well as mixing the colors, to open gates and successfully hack computers or other systems. None of these puzzles is overly-complex or obscure, and they are an enjoyable variation from the usual running and looking around for stuff.

For a $1 game, you can kind of guess what you're getting yourself into. It's a janky indy horror game. I wanna just say I was given a key for free to test this out.

Visually the game is okay. The walls of the apartment are probably the worst part. The textures are really weird and like overly large or something. Other than that, I honestly thought everything else looked fine. Not AAA, but it's an indie game, so I'm not gunna hold that against them.

Be warned that this is mostly cheap jump scares that play loud noises or make something suddenly appear in your face. I can't really say that the atmosphere was all that tense otherwise.

The gameplay is basically a puzzle game. You have to do certain things to advance the game forward until you get to the point that you need to solve a combination lock. This is where the game really got rough for me. The clues are very weird and I got lost for the most part. I managed to figure out what the two middle digits were, but the other two I had no idea. I looked around for about 15 minutes, getting more and more bored as nothing new was happening until I solved the puzzle. Thankfully another review has a youtube video showing the code. I just used that and moved on. The game ends shortly after that but the last few minutes are probably the best part of the game. It is a tad unsettling and plays with your head a little bit, which was nice. Although I'll admit it's all things that had been done before, but at least it was pulled off well.

The sound design is okay. As I said before, there are loud jump scare sounds, but there is also a subtle unsettling sound playing in the background, which was a nice touch. Also some eerie sounds will sometimes play just behind you, which did make things a bit more tense.

The story is pretty much non-existent. Based on the title, it seems you are a new tenet moving into a rental apartment? The landlord, I assume, leaves you a note saying they couldn't see you in person, so they left the key on a box. That's the story, there's nothing else I could glean from any of the other notes that had anything to do with the story. In fact most of the rest of the writing is really strange and made no sense to me. A lot to do with symmetry, but I dunno, I might just be too dumb to figure it out haha.

The game is mostly stable, I didn't have any crashes or anything like that. The game also doesn't have a save feature, but it really doesn't need it. If you can solve the combo lock puzzle quickly, you can beat this game in under 10 minutes. If you already know the combo, you could speed run this game in under 5 minutes I imagine.

I did run into 2 bugs though. First, if you close the pantry door in the kitchen while you are inside the pantry, you can push yourself into the corner where the door will open in to. Then open the door and hold the direction toward the wall and you will clip through the wall right into the fridge. You won't be able to escape and will softlock yourself. Honestly I found it kind of amusing.

Second bug was that you could manipulate the combo lock by just looking at it and pressing W or S. You didn't have to interact with it, you could just be walking around the kitchen, look over at it and hit one of those keys and it would scroll the numbers.

I'm giving this a thumbs up but honestly I don't think this game should be a paid game. That said, it's $1, and I think by now people should know what they're paying for when it comes to super cheap indie horror games. Personally I think the dev made a decent game for their skill level. I imagine they are probably just starting with game development and I always want to encourage new devs to try their hand at it. So congrats on making a game at all. That's more than a lot of people can say. Keep going and try to improve on your game making skills.

Shockingly good, honestly. I'd say this despite its scope is the best cultivation game I've played and I've played all the big ones. Its got a good variety in options for playstyle, feels mostly pretty fair and while some options are rather overtuned, its not like any feel completely unviable, as is often the case in these games where throw sword or lifesteal tends to be >>>> anything else.
The issues are:

Inconsistent tooltips. Some stats and effects say nothing when moused over. How much damage is '1 base damage'? Its not 1. What does it effect? I don't know. What is 'soul level', how do I grind it? I don't know. Its mostly fine, but some of the most important stats aren't transparent.

As mentioned, some blatantly superior or inferior options. Melee in general has super short range but doesn't do damage to justify this. The best melee weapon by far is ranged and requires a dozen upgrades that just buff it to compete with an average spell. One spell basically makes you invincible. % damage scaling off crit is the only damage buff that matters because of how much higher it is than anything else and % life/spirit steal quicky just restores 100% per hit as you start doing like 10k per hit.
One spell in particular, the upgraded meteor, seems outright bugged. It does '100x meteor damage' (which is absurd itself); this somehow made meteor go from 90 damage a hit to 32k+, 1 shotting over half the game. And that's per meteor. I was throwing 3 or more per cast. 

It has gungeon style combos where having certain weapons/items changes how a specifc item in the 'combo' works, but the only wayto see what works with what is very vague hints and unreadable (as so many weapons are swords or hammers and look similar) silouhettes. 

Personally I just plainly refused to use the uber broken options (demon cultivation healing its entire health per hit, meteor upgrade, turtle shield invul) and the game felt mostly fair like this. If you use any of those, its a joke. I DO use the broken % crit = damage upgrade, because of one of the main balancing issues:
Bosses have more hp than every enemy in their area combined. They're just insanely tanky for no apparent reason, to the point where if you don't have this, they can take minutes to kill despite every enemy already dying in one hit/

Its main issues lie in QoL with like 90% of its content feeling pretty well designed and balanced. Its not a perfect game or anything, but its much, much better than I expected for its price. 
I got it at 20% off which feels fair. 
Full price may be a bit much until they fix the QoL... which they won't do, since they're moving on to the next game. Which I hope is a sequel to this and fixes these issues. At which point I'd pay much more and be happy.

Everybody has that ONE game. A game so influential to them that it manages to sculpt and shape their views on what multiplayer gaming is supposed to be. For a lot of people, it is Halo, Counter-Strike or Call of Duty, just to name a few. For me, it was this game right here, [b]Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory[/b]. So influential in fact that this game partially helped shape my gamer nickname I use in almost every game and gaming platform. 

You can guess where I got the other half.

So, what's so special about this game? It's pretty much Team Fortress in WW2, it has very little to do with Wolfenstein beyond just being a generic WW2 setting and while the tone is decisively serious, almost imediately it turns comedically silly with all the voice lines (especially the german ones) and people bunnyhopping all over the place, not to mention the gratuitous amount of gore and gibs when using explosives and mortars.

This game was meant to be an expansion for Return to Castle Wolfenstein (fantastic game BTW), but for one reason or another, Splash Damage decided to release this game for free and completely stand-alone from the base game. Growing up as a broke teenager, this game was an absolute blessing and even when I started buying games with my own earned money, I still played the heck out of this one for a long while.

The original 2003 release only had 6 maps in total, but the WolfET community got up to the task of making even more maps, including porting the ones from RTCW, there's simply no shortage of maps to choose from, depending on your favorite server of course.

This game is one of many that used the old GameSpy services and unfortunately it got shut down a long time ago. Fortunately the community has managed to keep this game alive by rebuilding a master server list (look for [b]ET Legacy[/b]) and plenty of people willing to host their own servers, sometimes it feels like a different game with each server using a different set of mods and map rotation lists.

So, is it worth playing this game? ABSOLUTELY! ... With a caveat of course. First, this game won't work right out of the box, you need to install [b]ET Legacy[/b], not only does it revive the master server list, but it also brings many QoL improvements like a proper Alt+Tab command (the original famously didn't have such a thing), higher resolution and framerate support, better audio and many more MUCH needed improvements.

Second, your XP progress is entirely server dependent, it doesn't get saved account wise like in most multiplayer games and if you're hopping from server to server, you must be willing to start all over again in every new server you visit. It's not a big deal in my opinion, you can still be completely competitive at level 1, but you can definitely have more advantages and cooler weapons at higher levels.

And lastly, don't take this game too seriously, have fun, embrace the silliness and play this game to your heart's content, it's completely free and it most certainly runs on your kitchen fridge above 120 FPS.

It's a a prologue to a medieval story set in England, I highly suggest using saveeditonline.com or another save editor to cut the boring grind of playing in the highest difficulty and dying over and over again to start again with marginal improvements. The gameplay consists of picking activities in your army camp, each activity passes a bit of time and after time runs out you get a battle. The battles are typical turn based combat and it's fairly fleshed out, you can use different weapons, aim for different limbs and use things like poison to debuff enemies.

The good/pros: it's a fairly interesting if not wholly innovative story, your character is a young son of a small merchant near London, gets into a fight where the sheriff's son lies dead, so he flees from the hanging and joins an army going north to fight the Scots and their allied French. You meet a couple of characters and ultimately have to choose how to interact with them. If you like the setting, it's a pretty decent if short story.

The bad/cons: Personally, I hated the combat and checks of skill during events. Sure, the combat is kinda wide with all the weapons, stats, attacks and defenses, but it's ultimately shallow and you either grind a lot or set it to easy. There is a lot of RNG as well when it comes to your equipment, both from the available stock on the camp's mechant and to the loot you get. The best gear for me was a big shield and an one handed pike, but in most runs I couldn't quite get kitted out. Specially because looting dead enemies drains your virtue stat, kind of like your morality meter that comes into play sometimes. So, again, use an online save editor, max out your stats and then you don't need to worry about passing RNG checks. The alternative is playing on the highest difficulty, where each death gives you a couple of points to spend next time. I say the number checks should be scrapped, instead let players choose what they want and show the outcome, don't extend your gameplay with useless grinding.

Finally, the story is just the prologue, ultimately your arc is to realize that of the downfall mentioned in the title. You are just a cog in a war machine now, this is your life, you cannot go back home ever again or you will hang. If anything, it could have easily been a Ren'Py visual novel, specially because the choices are not going to really carry through to the next part. [spoiler] You will be used, betrayed by most people and those that don't betray you are going to end up dead. So the only people left are those you either want to kill or flee from, one of which appears as the last boss all of a sudden is implied to become your target for revenge.[/spoiler] You are also going to lose pretty much everything you own, so the next game can start you from zero anyway.

[h1] A mess of a review: [/h1]

[u] Tl,dr: [/u]

There's potential here, but development seems slow. I'd wait a bit after the full release to see if the game arrives in a somewhat finished and polished state.

[u] First concerns: [/u]

Having played the Demo that came out in June of 2022, before this Prologue, I'm a bit worried about the development of this game. The Prologue felt like a slightly more enhanced version of the Demo (with added day/night cycle, some more recipes and objects to place), which makes it seem like the game didn't come very far in that year.
On top of that the game currently is still in a fairly buggy state; I had to repeat days because the tutorials broke on me several times, one day I just couldn't finish because the "go home" objective never popped up, plates seem to multiply on their own and so on.
Another point of concern is the lack of the multiplayer. Sure this is just a Prologue, however I'm concerned that the developers are struggling with the actual implementation of the multiplayer in the game, which in my personal opinion, would be the biggest selling point of this game.

[u] Mechanics: [/u]

The addition of the service counters is a bit questionable in my opinion, since you make one dish and somehow you can serve 4 of them, which kind of takes away from the cooking aspect of the game.
Washing dishes is novel at first but maybe the addition of a dishwasher would be a good idea to automate this task so the player can focus more on the actual cooking.
The build mode, although a little basic, is fun and lets you customize your own restaurant quite well.
Cooking is fun. Let the player do more of that please.
Somehow the restaurant gets miraculously trashed overnight, it would be nicer if you would see the floors get dirty throughout the day or you have customers litter throughout the day, rather than a trash heap spawning in the restaurant overnight.
There is a progression system in the game and it seem to work fairly fine.
You can make pies and so on, however for some reason you have to free-place the crust into the tray in individual slices, which can get a bit finicky. I'd prefer either putting the entire crust at once or allowing the player to snap them into place.
I had customers come in and get annoyed at me for not having enough tables, although 20 seats were free/each customer wanted a separate table for some reason.

[u] Summary: [/u]

Despite the current shortcomings of the game i still see the same potential here that the demo had. Cooking, Customization and serving customers are all fun. There are bugs but those can be fixed. I'm not sure whether or not I can recommend this game at this point. Going by the current state of this prologue I'd say no, development seemed fairly slow and there was too little communication from the devs throughout the last year. By the looks of it multiplayer hasn't been implemented yet either. However there is so much potential here to make an actual fun co-op cooking simulator. On a side note the devs should maybe think about adding VR support to this game too, as this could easily become the best VR cooking game, especially once the multiplayer works. However, the prologue was playable and despite the bugs I had fun, especially when the tutorials wouldn't restrict what I was doing anymore.

[B][U]This review was made while the game was free (before patch 1.0.6 - July 29th). I plan to update it soon, consider it out of date until then.[/u][/b]

[h1][u]Synopsis[/u][/h1]
[i]Burial Stone[/i] is a medieval-fantasy first person grid-&-turn-based RPG that requires a VR headset and motion controllers to play. It contains fantasy violence, some blood, and comically over-sized bones spread throughout the dungeon's levels. It can be rather quiet, leading to an eerie sensation of being alone. There's very little in the way of music, and no story to speak of. During my time, I didn't encounter any game-breaking bugs, but one achievement seems to be bugged (Entered Boss Hall). The weapons might also be unselected in the menu despite being visually equipped, but I didn't notice this having an adverse effect on gameplay. The final screen is also far too long, and could use a skip button, or be shortened.

[h1][u]In and out, quicker than you'd think[/u][/h1]
[u][b]Introduction[/b][/u]
It makes me feel like a monster to not recommend. It's free, so you're not losing anything financially. However, you are devoting your time while playing it as opposed to any numerous other tasks or games you could be playing. If the game had something going for it, a novelty of some kind, I would give it an immediate thumbs up. This is clearly a passion project being soldiered by most likely one person. Which is highly unfortunate, as there is nary a thing I can recall for the hour of playing that warrants a download. It's lacking in a lot of fundamental ways, and what is present is rather cumbersome, and to be honest, not very well implemented.

[b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]
This game doesn't feel particularly fun to play. Movement in a grid-based game locks you to the board, and this restriction can breed innovative design. In Burial Stone, it simply limits the player with no benefit, other than preventing the player from running into walls or getting stuck against the scenery. The UI doesn't play nice while moving either, which can be annoying when you just want to click on a healing item while on the go.

Combat is clunky and unrewarding, highly RNG based on whether you hit, and how devastating you are. You'll watch in dismay as one of your skills or spells fails to produce any meaningful damage if it hits. When it doesn't, you've wasted mana, and the enemy may have struck you with considerable damage. Which results in you fumbling your next turn to chug a healing item or potion, which can be very rare early on. Almost every enemy is functionally the same, minus some status effects or use of range weaponry, both from singular entities. It's all very bland and straightforward, even the final boss lacks in mechanical depth.

All this leading to the biggest disappointment, the interactivity. VR has its place in gaming, wherein most games are going to be short and provide some level of gameplay immersion inaccessible without the headset. Pulling levers, swinging swords, and physically leaning around corners are all elements that are gimmicky in nature, but are satisfying in their own way. None of this is present in any capacity. You click on skills to make your next attack do that. You click on levers to make them open doors. You click on items in menus to buy, use or equip them (if the game doesn't do that for you sometimes). The game totes that your only source of light is the torch, but it might as well be light emanating from you to begin with, because it's never used in any meaningful manner. It calls into question why it even needed to be a VR game, it would've work about as well not in VR.

All this, yet I can still see the potential here, a lot of ideas that need exploring to flesh out the game into something that could honestly be rather enjoyable and unique. A lot of VR tends to require the player to be constantly active, it's nice when one comes along that plays at the pace of the player's decisions.

[h1][u]Dungeon Crawling Core Value[/u][/h1]
Burial Stone is a dungeon crawler defined by the older, classical descriptive used to identify a type of game from the 80s/90s; a grid-based first person rpg, sometimes referred to as a gridder, or blobber if it contains more than one actively controlled protagonist. The inherit core value of the experience is, in my opinion, a level 2.

"The game contains dungeons and/or dungeon-like environments that serves the purpose of scenery or change of scenery. The environment has little significance, but overall attempts to present a dungeon crawling experience in some way other than purely/entirely cosmetic."

The whole experience is an immersive one to a degree, and can often feel rather eerie in the silence, with only the sounds of your torch breaking up the quiet. However, the lack of interactivity hurts it greatly. It's like a horror house where you get to see the things, but always keep a modest distance from them.

[h1][u]Final Thoughts[/u][/h1]
I didn't want this is come off so negative. In the end, it's free. If you want to give it a shot and have a VR headset, there's nothing really stopping you. It's an hour of your time, and if you feel like it's worth marveling at a passion project, then don't let me stop you. It's a quaint game, and you might enjoy it. Heck, it could be the inspiration you need to start your own project.

Brutal old-school difficulty packed in cute little aesthetics.

The game opts for minimalistic art and basic color. If the default colors aren't to your liking, there are other color templates available in the options. Some are too bright for my taste, but a few are exactly ideal for the game. 

The gameplay is typical of a platformer, featuring jumping and attacking. There is no tutorial, but I wish there was one to teach you about unique abilities. These are in limited supply and utilize animals with special attacks. All three feel completely useless because of weak attacks.

Despite its attractive looks and appearance, the game is as tough as nails. Although you can pick between lower and higher difficulty levels, normal is the best way to receive the whole experience. In any case, there isn't much of a difference because it simply affects the damage you receive.

The majority of the annoyance stems from knockback and instant death when falling into pits. When both are present, death always follows. There are way too many situations in which you must jump on platforms, but contact with an enemy knocks you into a hole. Naturally, enemy placement is ideal for this to occur. There are, thankfully, checkpoints.

The game's balance needs to be improved. I frequently just rushed to the next checkpoint or took an intentional hit that grants you a second of invincibility to get through a difficult section. Another disadvantage is that your character's attack is very weak. 

You'll have to kill cute animals like butterflies, cats, and frogs. They can, however, take multiple hits and attack relentlessly. While attacking in the air is okay, attacking on the ground prevents you from moving for a split second. As you might expect, bosses have attacks that require fast reaction. Second and fourth boss are unplayable because of fast random attacks that are impossible to dodge. I had to rely on a another secret move; press up and jump.

If you choose to delete your save file when on stage 2 and restart the game, you may encounter a glitch. The new file will begin in Chapter 2 and will display a white screen, rendering the game unplayable. This can be resolved by exiting and restarting the game.

The game is still in early access and doesn’t cost much, but I would recommend this only to those who are familiar with old-school experience that borders on unfair. It's not fun for anyone else.

[b]  Dolmenjord [/b] is a Casual Sorting Puzzle game.  

There is no setup story for the game. All of the puzzles deal with placing tiles on a board of different sizes and making sure all pieces fit on the map.  There is the added complexity of specific pieces either needing to connect to each other or face a certain way to be considered a complete map.

The game is very complicated in later stages unless you use the hint feature to show how to place the boardwalk. Play time is ~1 hour to get all achievements, and ~3-5 hours to beat all maps. I recommend this game to anyone that likes casual games or is an achievement hunter.

When I first played Rat Clan I thought it was terrible, it felt entirely too weak with way more downsides than upsides, and I across multiple games I was always struggling for enough food. I kept trying though, and now Clan of the Rat is my favorite clan to play. 
It doesn't change the game like Dragon or Kraken, just uses the base game mechanics to create an entirely new play perspective, where the villagers themselves are more of a resource than they're ever been. Go heavy into food production and mining rock to upgrade to food production buildings, and choose Overcrowding as your first or second perk, and you won't have problems with food again (as long as you have a decent spawn point). I used to cringe at the loss of every villager from wolf attacks with other clans, now you immediately have ones to replace. Production low? Overwork, kill off the villagers whose health is too low to recover in a reasonable amount of time. I love the ability of Eir and the shamans to heal themselves on long conquests and guerilla attacks across the map so you don't have to eternally return to your own territory to heal. It's great for hit and run raids and by the time you build up you can get your pyre monster to tank damage for you. 
It's also nice you can Overwork at any time, not like Feasts where you have to save up more and more food every time. 

Is it the most powerful clan, no. But the large number of rapidly appearing villagers allow you to dump them into whatever victory path you've decided, so in my opinion it's more versatile. 
I also like how you don't have to use Houses, and now when I go back to other clans it's frustrating that I lose so many building slots to them XD 

Not for everyone I guess, but I'm a fan.
